awd_titl_txt: Search for Neutrinoless Double Beta Decay in 136Xe
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will enable this group to continue to study whether the mass of the neutrino is of a Majorana or Dirac nature. This question is of fundamental importance for our understanding of matter at the smallest scales, and the answer is likely to shed light on physics beyond the standard model. The group's investigations will take place within the context of the EXO-200 double beta decay experiment, the world's most sensitive search for Majorana neutrino masses. The award will provide support for their involvement in EXO-200 through its data taking and analysis phases.

This support will create additional broader impacts outside the field of neutrino physics, primarily by training a graduate student in the methods of experimental science, and by demonstrating experimental techniques and technologies which have applications in other areas of pure and applied science.

por.por_cntn:
The EXO-200 experiment is dedicated to enhancing our understanding of the basic properties of neutrinos, a type of fundamental particle. The experiment seaches for rare or exotic decay of atomic nuclei in a bath of liquefied xenon. By measuring or ruling out these rare decay modes, the experiment can constrain properties of the neutrino such as its mass and its charge properties. The experiment is one of the most sensitive of its kind in the world. It operates 2150 feet underground at the WIPP facility, near Carlsbad, New Mexico. The experiment has published its results in peer reviewed journals such as Nature and the Physical Review. Its most prominent result is a sensitive search for neutrinoless double beta decay of 136Xe, which set new limits on the mass and nature of the neutrino. It also made the first observation of the very rare two-neutrino double beta decay of the 136Xe nucleus, and measured the half-life for this decay to be about 2 x 10^21 years, with a precision of 2.83%. We have also developed new techniques to identify and reduce the effect of coherent electrical noise across many readout channels. This technique had implications for noise reduction and pattern recognition in many fields.
